item.description:
Finishing the prep work for New Rustacean e018.

Have I mentioned lately that I love Rust? Because I really, really do.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Was delighted to be a guest on the new Remote Works Podcast! These guys are making a great show. (My episode will be out in February.)
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Registering a new domain for a new podcast I’m doing with Jaimie. It’s going to be massively fun.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
I’m extremely excited to be adding a new format to New Rustacean: discussing good crates in the Rust ecosystem. Suggestions wanted!

Crates You Should Know: quick-xml—A pull-parser for reading and writing XML.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Started writing the script for the first “Crates You Should Know” episode of New Rustacean tonight. I’m pretty excited about adding this format to the repertoire.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 6 of 6
item.description: Some big goals for 2017, and some smaller ones too.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 5 of 6
item.description: My strategy for productivity: less social media, careful use of my time, and embracing the "pomodoro technique".
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Things on my podcasting to-buy-in-2017 list: Rogue Amoeba’s Loopback!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 4 of 6
item.description: Olo is great; I helped build (almost from scratch) a large mobile web application; I did some open-source software; it was a good year professionally.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 3 of 6
item.description: On top of my 200,000 words of writing this year, I also published some 66 episodes and almost 20 hours of podcasting across four different shows.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 2 of 6
item.description: One of my goals for 2016 was to continue writing not only on this blog but in other outlets. I did a *lot* of writing this year, but relatively little of it is published. But here's a look at some of the numbers! (And they are large!)
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 1 of 6
item.description: Accidental 20-mile runs, walking pneumonia, gaining weight because of metabolic shifts, and other adventures in my "fitness" in 2016.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Introduction
item.description: 2016 was a long, difficult, strange, sometimes wonderful and sometimes dreadful year for me. It was one of the most professionally and scholastically enjoyable and rewarding years of my life, and also one of the most exhausting. As I often do at years-end, I am taking stock publicly of what went well, what went poorly, and what I might do different in a variety of categories!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Just recorded Winning Slowly 5.09 with Slack calls—super pleased with Audio Hijack’s support for it!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Editing one of the most pure fun episodes of Winning Slowly we’ve ever done.

It’s about libraries.

Yep.

Libraries.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Winning Slowly 5.05: “Faint Not”
item.description:
This is one of the most important episodes Stephen Carradini and I have ever published. We go after civil forfeiture hard. Give it a listen!

Winning Slowly 5.05: “Faint Not”—Negative / Invisible / Legal (Organized): civil forfeiture and entrenched legal evil
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
I just realized: like a complete dolt, I forgot to update the show feed for Winning Slowly when I published 5.04. :facepalm:

Looks like subscribers get two episodes in their feed today. 😬
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 32 Theses (and several more words) on Podcasting
item.description:
A month ago, Alan Jacobs asked about quality conservative Christian podcasts. Here’s a big part of why there are so few (at Mere Orthodoxy):

As a Christian in the world of podcasting—I have both a “two dudes talking” show (Winning Slowly) and also a “one dude talking with …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Winning Slowly Season 5
item.description:
Up the ante, you say? Sure, we’ll tackle the small, easy problem of systemic force and individual agency this season on Winning Slowly.

5.01: A Ph.D.-Level Math Problem—Structures and systems, agency and individuals: three axes (and a sub-axis) for thinking about the world we live …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Wrote 700 words of the script for New Rustacean e017. Should finish that script tomorrow (and maybe record, too!).
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Speaking of podcasting: my current goal is to ship an episode of New Rustacean every other week (the off weeks from Winning Slowly), after this coming week (when they’ll hopefully both have an episode). Lots to do!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Just made the requisite website tweaks for Winning Slowly Season 5!

5.01 coming Tuesday. GET EXCITED.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Finished the New Rustacean material for e016. But I’m sick, so now I’m going to bed. Bleh.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I didn’t get done everything I hoped, but I read a bunch and wrote a bunch for New Rustacean e016. Hoping to release it this week!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Recorded a fantastic New Rustacean interview with Raph Levien this afternoon. Part 1 should be up tonight!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Listening to Harry Greyson-Williams’ score for The Martian 🎵 and finishing the New Rustacean e015 script. 🎙
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: The New Rustacean Patreon supporters are awesome. Today, I massively upgraded my recording set up. And it sounds fantastic.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
When I podcast, I don’t do “just news.” I do “news I MEAN describe how MIR changes the Rust compiler flow”:

▶ New Rustacean News 1: One year and counting—on Rust a year in, including an overview of how the compiler works
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Recorded another New Rustacean episode at last; it should be up this afternoon. Rust FTW!

And, me being me, this “news” episode ended up with a description of how the Rust compiler works. 🤓 It’ll post later!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Wrote ~1,000 words of the next New Rustacean episode—including a new (occasional) episode format on recent news in the Rust community!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
I’m totally working a reference to Daniel Spreadbury’s SMuFL work into a discussion of Rust’s Unicode support in New Rustacean e014.

(This has to be the nerdiest thing I’ve ever done. Even in context, this is over the top.)
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I’m drafting the next episode of New Rustacean on a 3-year-old retina iPad Mini and I love it. An iPad Pro looks awfully appealing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Run With Me!
item.description:
I may have gone mad with power or something, but I launched another podcast today! Crazy, I know.

It’s both more and less crazy than it might sound, though. More, because of what the podcast is, and less, because of what the podcast is. So what is it?

Run …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I would love a simple, static, podcast-friendly site generator. (Pelican works, and I know it well enough, but I don’t love it.) Thoughts?
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Successfully recorded the first episode of a new micro-podcast called Run With Me. Will be live later this week!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: The new Overcast feature which lets patrons upload custom files is the best for podcasters verifying episodes before release.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: A really nice update to the podcast app I use every day. Props to Marco Arment!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
If you want cloud storage—e.g. to back a CDN—and want an alternative to Amazon S3, check out DreamHost’s DreamObjects. It’s great—and inexpensive!

I’ve been using it for Winning Slowly and New Rustacean downloads for 9 months. Couldn’t be happier with the results …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Speaking of podcasting, the episode of Winning Slowly we published today—and interview with Ghost’s co-founder John O’Nolan—is one of my favorite episodes of the show we’ve done. He’s cogent, thoughtful, and on point throughout; the episode is well worth your time!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: My wife has a voice made for podcasting. I’m editing the newest episode of Sap.py (!) and listening to her speak is simply sublime.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: After doing a little looking around, I’ve concluded that Blubrry is likely to be the best replacement for Podtrac for my purposes. Giving it a spin now. It’s not especially beautiful or amazing, but it’s no worse than Podtrac… and it performs way better.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Okay, I’m basically done with PodTrac at this point. It’s slow to use, slow to update, and now it isn’t showing me anything about recent episodes on the dashboard. Anyone have a good podcasting analytics tool to recommend?
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Static Site Generators and Podcasting
item.description: Presently, I publish both Winning Slowly and New Rustacean1 using what is admittedly a bit of a quirky approach. It works well for me, and I think it’s worth documenting for other nerdy types out there, but if you’re just getting going with podcasting and you’re …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: One of these days I should write up the slightly arcane workflow I use to publish Winning Slowly and New Rustacean. It’s weird.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
I’ve set up a podcast feed specifically for any sermons I preach going forward. You can subscribe these places:

  • iTunes
  • Overcast
  • Pocket Casts
  • Direct

As an aside: having done the starting-up dance for 4 podcasts now, it’s gotten pretty easy. 😉
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Spent the last little bit reading about Rust’s type system for the next episode of New Rustacean. Heady stuff.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: The setup I used to get reasonable-sounding audio out of Skype this morning. God bless Rogue Amoeba’s Audio Hijack.

item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Published my tenth full episode (and twelfth total) of New Rustacean today. Researching for, writing, recording, and editing the 17-minute, 23-second episode took a total of seven and a half hours.

Podcasting is a lot of work, but I still really enjoy it.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Editing Winning Slowly 4.01 for release on Tuesday. I accidentally did a 5 minute monologue—apparently I’m used to soloing on New Rustacean!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Thoughts on 2015 (and 2016)
item.description: As we come to the end of the year, I have been reflecting on the things I set out to do this year, and on my hopes for the coming year. At the start of the year, I posted a number of goals for my “public” life this year, and …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Here’s a thing I’m quite okay with:
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Today, I edited and published Sap.py 1 and recorded, edited, and published New Rustacean e01. A nice, productive day of podcasting!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Winning Slowly 3.09 runs to 42:10—after 7 hours of editing that cut out quite a bit of material. I think all our listeners will appreciate the final result, though; I can’t wait to share it with all of you on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: On Editing Podcasts
item.description: Most podcasts are more like blog posts than magazine articles. (That doesn't mean you shouldn't edit, them, though!)
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: CDN configured. Sites both 80% done. These podcasts will launch this week, unless something goes particularly sideways.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: The domain configuration for Sap.py and New Rustacean is done, and the websites are coming along. Almost ready!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Hooked up my digital piano to Logic Pro X tonight and wrote the theme for a podcast we’re doing together on learning to program. It’s so good!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: A minute ago, Ellie asked me to play with her and Kate. I started to answer, “No, I need to finish publishing Winning Slowly.” Then I remembered: putting that first would be pretty much exactly the opposite of Winning Slowly.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Hey, Look—A Podcast!
item.description: Today, I was happy to be able to finally go public with a project on which I have been working for the last couple months (and for which I have been planning since mid-fall): Winning Slowly. Winning Slowly is a biweeklypodcast by yours truly and my good friend Stephen Carradini …
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho
